body: What version/platform are you running?  Can you share the image that is causing the issues?

windows 7
python 2.7.8, and python 3.4.2, for both python versions
VERSION = '1.1.7'  # PIL version
PILLOW_VERSION = '2.7.0'  # Pillow

the image is shared on dropbox 
https://www.dropbox.com/s/eannbvbgiwskq7e/bmg1.bmp?dl=0

I can reproduce on Windows 7 with Python 2.7.8 and Pillow 2.7.0:

``` python
from PIL import Image
aoi = (1, 1, 10, 10)
img = Image.open('bmg1.bmp')
img = img.crop(aoi)
img.show()
```

Wrapping `try`/`except` doesn't catch anything.

It works fine with hopper.png.

Strangely, if I stick `import ipdb; ipdb.set_trace()` into [line 64 at the top of `Viewer`'s `show()`](https://github.com/python-pillow/Pillow/blob/master/PIL/ImageShow.py#L64) to step through with [ipdb](http://www.gregaker.net/2012/apr/05/debugging-python-with-pdb-or-ipdb/) (the IPython debugger), it works fine for both images (and both give `Exception AttributeError: "'NoneType' object has no attribute 'path'" in <function _remove at 0x0000000001E0ADD8> ignored` when the test script exits).

Problem also exists in Pillow 2.3.0, 2.4.0, 2.5.0, 2.6.2.

Windows event log:

```
Faulting application name: python.exe, version: 0.0.0.0, time stamp: 0x53b1ee02
Faulting module name: MSVCR90.dll, version: 9.0.30729.6161, time stamp: 0x4dace4e7
Exception code: 0xc0000005
Fault offset: 0x000000000001e28f
Faulting process id: 0x12e0
Faulting application start time: 0x01d030e16b080e1e
Faulting application path: c:\Python27\python.exe
Faulting module path: C:\Windows\WinSxS\amd64_microsoft.vc90.crt_1fc8b3b9a1e18e3b_9.0.30729.6161_none_08e61857a83bc251\MSVCR90.dll
Report Id: a9e681a6-9cd4-11e4-a980-005056c00002
```

```
Fault bucket , type 0
Event Name: APPCRASH
Response: Not available
Cab Id: 0

Problem signature:
P1: python.exe
P2: 0.0.0.0
P3: 53b1ee02
P4: MSVCR90.dll
P5: 9.0.30729.6161
P6: 4dace4e7
P7: c0000005
P8: 000000000001e28f
P9: 
P10: 

```
It's not doing it on linux here, and there's nothing fishy about the BMP that I can see.
Is there a way to get a stack trace from the crash?  At least if we could get back to where we're calling into MSVCR90.dll.

The crash produces three files:
- WER993E.tmp.WERInternalMetadata.xml
- WERB171.tmp.appcompat.txt
- WERB1C0.tmp.mdmp

The xml is mainly the APPCRASH info above. The txt shows things like exe and dll versions. TThe mdpmp is a binary "mini dump file" abnd probably what is needed. Windows debugging tools are needed, and need to point to a Windows symbol server to interpret. I can't get the debugging tools installed right now. Would you like me to email them over?

It crashes at https://github.com/python-pillow/Pillow/blob/master/libImaging/Paste.c#L55
Looks like `imIn->image` is pointing to a bad pointer.
Locals:

```
+       imOut   0x0000000001fad7f0 {mode=0x0000000001fad7f0 "L" type=0 depth=0 ...} ImagingMemoryInstance *
-       imIn    0x0000000001fad850 {mode=0x0000000001fad850 "L" type=0 depth=0 ...} ImagingMemoryInstance *
```

The Dropbox URL is no longer working. Any chance that a link can be provided to the test image again?
it doesn't matter what bmp, any  rgb valued .bmp image gives this error.
@hugovk Can you check to see if the BMP changes in 3.3.0 have fixed this?
I won't be able to check Windows until tomorrow. Can anyone else check it?
I think `Tests/images/bmp/g/pal8-0.bmp` triggers the bug. I'm currently unable to get anything out of appveyor with it.

It looks like there's a use after free on the core image structure, but from my traces of it, it doesn't appear that the memory is actually freed. It shouldn't happen, because we're keeping a reference to the core image structure in the new `_ImageCrop` object.

The problem appears to go away if we make a copy of the core image object in `_ImageCrop.__init__` rather than a pointer to it. Copying the image removes the entire point of having a lazy crop in the first place. 

(not that it makes a huge amount of sense anyway -- it's the one lazy operation other than load, and it requires the initial image to be loaded anyway.  I think this is one place where the complexity is not worth it. )
Also, cropping a `P` image didn't retain the palette, and didn't return a PyAccess object where appropriate.

issue.title: Make Image.crop an immediate operation, not lazy.
issue.body:
Fixes #1077 .

Changes proposed in this pull request:
- `Image.crop` is now immediate, and returns a new image object
- All the important fields are copied over, using the _new function, including the palette
- `_ImageCrop` is now gone.
- Fixes an access violation that looks like a use after free on windows.

((probably should have release notes))

body: Is it not possible to lazy crop anymore? I'm trying to operate over very large images (eg: 100k x 100k ) and loading the entire image to do a crop is not feasible.

From my investigation, it is the loading of the cropped image that is no longer lazy. It always loaded the image before the crop operation was performed.

That answer doesn't particularly help you though. Are you interested in a particular format of images? I would suggest creating a new issue if you would like this to become a feature of Pillow.
